Welcome from the Chair Welcome to NYU Steinhardt's Department of Physical Therapy, located in the Gramercy section of New York City and close to world-class teaching hospitals. Read More.    Doctor of Physical Therapy a 3-year post-baccalaureate professional doctoral degree program to prepare students for a career in physical therapy    Doctor of Physical Therapy for Practicing Physical Therapists a program to enable physical therapists in practice to upgrade their knowledge base to the DPT degree level    Master of Arts Program for Physical Therapists a post-professional program with a concentration in pathokinesiology to prepare physical therapists with clinical research skills in analysis and synthesis of human motion    Doctor of Philosophy Program for Physical Therapists a post-professional program to prepare physical therapists for academic research careers in the profession of physical therapy    Clinical Residency in Orthopedic Physical Therapy a program designed so that licensed physical therapists can obtain advanced orthopedic knowledge and clinical skills    Weekend Intensives in Orthopedic Physical Therapy advanced training in orthopedic practice to physical therapists in an immersive Friday/Saturday format.                  This site, and all its contents, are Copyright ©    by New York University. All rights reserved.   NYU Steinhardt - Physical Therapy - 380 Second Avenue, 4th Floor, New York,  NY 10010

Permalink |          Email |     Share on: Facebook |       Twitter                                            Information Session for the Doctor of Physical Therapy Program                            REGISTRATION REQUIRED     OPEN HOUSE for the Doctor of Physical Therapy Program     Thursday, March 26, 2015     6:00 PM - 8:00 PM    Capacity: 60 people                        Program Overview      The course of study for the Doctor of Physical Therapy (DPT) Program begins in the summer semester and continues on a full-time basis for three years, including three summers of supervised clinical practice. This innovative entry-level program encompasses the study of normal and abnormal structure and function and the theory and practice of physical therapy. Students obtain clinical experience in a variety of hospitals, rehabilitation centers, schools for children with physically disabling conditions, nursing homes, private practices, and public health agencies. The student is awarded a professional doctoral degree upon completion of the program, is eligible to sit for licensure, and is prepared to practice in a clinical setting. The Doctor of Physical Therapy Program aims to develop competent, autonomous practitioners with the expertise and skills to:       Examination of patients/clients across the life span for impairments, functional limitations, and disabilities and for prevention, wellness, fitness, and health promotion needs.    Provide interventions across the life span for the management of injury, impairments, functional limitations, and disabilities;    Maintain and promote fitness, wellness, health, and quality of life;    Ensure availability, accessibility, and excellence in the delivery of physical therapy services to patients/clients across the life span;    Serve as an educator, screener, administrator, consultant, delegator, and manager;    Assume leadership roles in prevention and health maintenance programs and rehabilitation services;    Utilize research to support practice;    Impart information to colleagues;    Assist in the development of and advocate for health policy standards tied to physical therapy practice; and    Establish a plan for professional development and life long learning.       The Doctor of Physical Therapy Program at New York University is accredited by the Commission on Accreditation in Physical Therapy Education (CAPTE), 111 North Fairfax Street, Alexandria, Virginia 22314; telephone: 703-706-3245; accreditation@apta.org ; website                                      Program Director    Marilyn Moffat, PT, DPT, PhD, DSc (hon), GCS, CSCS, CEEAA, FAPTA Professor of Physical Therapy Phone: 212-998-9400 Email: mm8@nyu.edu     Outcomes    Based on information collected on the classes of 2010, 2011, and 2012, the Program student outcomes were as follows: the three-year graduation rate was 94.36%; the three-year licensure exam pass rate was 100% and the three-year employment rate was 97.43%. For the class of 2013, the graduation rate was 98.96%; the licensure exam pass rate was 100% and the employment rate was 100% .    Student Body    The Doctor of Physical Therapy (DPT) Program is open to students holding a baccalaureate degree with the appropriate prerequisites. Our students come from varied academic, cultural, and experience backgrounds, which make our student body one of the most unique in the country. Students have baccalaureate degrees that range from a to z (from anthropology, business, dance, exercise science, psychology, to zoology).               This site, and all its contents, are Copyright ©    by New York University. All rights reserved.   NYU Steinhardt - Physical Therapy - 380 Second Avenue, 4th Floor, New York,  NY 10010

Permalink |          Email |     Share on: Facebook |       Twitter                                            Overview of the Department of Physical Therapy                                   Individuals who have not yet received physical therapy professional education and would like to pursue a career in physical therapy, should apply to the Doctor of Physical Therapy Program.    Individuals who have completed their physical therapy professional education are eligible for: the MA Program in Pathokinesiology, the Doctor of Physical Therapy Program for Practicing Physical Therapists, the PhD Program in Pathokinesiology, and the Clinical Residency Program in Orthopedic Physical Therapy.    Program Specific Requirements       Doctor of Physical Therapy    Doctor of Physical Therapy Degree for Practicing Therapists    Master of Arts Concentration for Physical Therapists    Ph.D Program    Clinical Residency Program in Orthopedic Physical Therapy                  This site, and all its contents, are Copyright ©    by New York University. Doctor of Physical Therapy a 3-year post-baccalaureate professional doctoral degree program to prepare students for a career in physical therapy    Doctor of Physical Therapy for Practicing Physical Therapists a program to enable physical therapists in practice to upgrade their knowledge base to the DPT degree level    Master of Arts Program for Physical Therapists a post-professional program with a concentration in pathokinesiology to prepare physical therapists with clinical research skills in analysis and synthesis of human motion    Doctor of Philosophy Program for Physical Therapists a post-professional program to prepare physical therapists for academic research careers in the profession of physical therapy    Clinical Residency in Orthopedic Physical Therapy a program designed so that licensed physical therapists can obtain advanced orthopedic knowledge and clinical skills    Weekend Intensives in Orthopedic Physical Therapy advanced training in orthopedic practice to physical therapists in an immersive Friday/Saturday format. Permalink |          Email |     Share on: Facebook |       Twitter                                            Overview of the Department of Physical Therapy                                   Individuals who have not yet received physical therapy professional education and would like to pursue a career in physical therapy, should apply to the Doctor of Physical Therapy Program.    Individuals who have completed their physical therapy professional education are eligible for: the MA Program in Pathokinesiology, the Doctor of Physical Therapy Program for Practicing Physical Therapists, the PhD Program in Pathokinesiology, and the Clinical Residency Program in Orthopedic Physical Therapy. Permalink |          Email |     Share on: Facebook |       Twitter                                            Information Session for the Doctor of Physical Therapy Program                            REGISTRATION REQUIRED     OPEN HOUSE for the Doctor of Physical Therapy Program     Thursday, March 26, 2015     6:00 PM - 8:00 PM    Capacity: 60 people                        Program Overview      The course of study for the Doctor of Physical Therapy (DPT) Program begins in the summer semester and continues on a full-time basis for three years, including three summers of supervised clinical practice. This innovative entry-level program encompasses the study of normal and abnormal structure and function and the theory and practice of physical therapy. Students obtain clinical experience in a variety of hospitals, rehabilitation centers, schools for children with physically disabling conditions, nursing homes, private practices, and public health agencies. The student is awarded a professional doctoral degree upon completion of the program, is eligible to sit for licensure, and is prepared to practice in a clinical setting. The Doctor of Physical Therapy Program aims to develop competent, autonomous practitioners with the expertise and skills to:       Examination of patients/clients across the life span for impairments, functional limitations, and disabilities and for prevention, wellness, fitness, and health promotion needs.    Provide interventions across the life span for the management of injury, impairments, functional limitations, and disabilities;    Maintain and promote fitness, wellness, health, and quality of life;    Ensure availability, accessibility, and excellence in the delivery of physical therapy services to patients/clients across the life span;    Serve as an educator, screener, administrator, consultant, delegator, and manager;    Assume leadership roles in prevention and health maintenance programs and rehabilitation services;    Utilize research to support practice;    Impart information to colleagues;    Assist in the development of and advocate for health policy standards tied to physical therapy practice; and    Establish a plan for professional development and life long learning.       The Doctor of Physical Therapy Program at New York University is accredited by the Commission on Accreditation in Physical Therapy Education (CAPTE), 111 North Fairfax Street, Alexandria, Virginia 22314; telephone: 703-706-3245; accreditation@apta.org ; website                                      Program Director    Marilyn Moffat, PT, DPT, PhD, DSc (hon), GCS, CSCS, CEEAA, FAPTA Professor of Physical Therapy Phone: 212-998-9400 Email: mm8@nyu.edu     Outcomes    Based on information collected on the classes of 2010, 2011, and 2012, the Program student outcomes were as follows: the three-year graduation rate was 94.36%; the three-year licensure exam pass rate was 100% and the three-year employment rate was 97.43%. For the class of 2013, the graduation rate was 98.96%; the licensure exam pass rate was 100% and the employment rate was 100% .    Student Body    The Doctor of Physical Therapy (DPT) Program is open to students holding a baccalaureate degree with the appropriate prerequisites. Our students come from varied academic, cultural, and experience backgrounds, which make our student body one of the most unique in the country. Students have baccalaureate degrees that range from a to z (from anthropology, business, dance, exercise science, psychology, to zoology).
